str2: And, even, also, namely.
All, the whole, every kind of. Including all the forms of declension; apparently a primary word; all, any, every, the whole.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From aggello; a messenger; especially an 'angel'; by implication, a pastor.

parse: Verb - Pluperfect Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: A prolonged form of a primary stao stah'-o; to stand, used in various applications.
A circle, ring. As if dative case of kuklos; i.e. In a circle, i.e. all around.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From thrao; a stately seat; by implication, power or a potentate.
And, even, also, namely.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Comparative of presbus; older; as noun, a senior; specially, an Israelite Sanhedrist or Christian 'presbyter'.
And, even, also, namely.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Four. Or neuter tessara a plural number; four.
An animal, living creature. Neuter of a derivative of zao; a live thing, i.e. An animal.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: A reduplicated and contracted form of peto; probably akin to petomai through the idea of alighting; to fall.
Neuter of a compound of en and a derivative of optanomai; in the face of.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
From thrao; a stately seat; by implication, power or a potentate.
And, even, also, namely.

parse: Verb - Aorist Indicative Active - 3rd Person Plural
str2: From pros and a probable derivative of kuon; to fawn or crouch to, i.e. prostrate oneself in homage.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
